fields.value: Ordinary mobility detected by call detail records along 2014

authorAffiliation.value: Federal University of Rio de Janeiro

datasetContactAffiliation.value: Federal University of Rio de Janeiro

dsDescriptionValue.value: These data sets contain the aggregated values of human mobility detected by CDR in the MRRJ (21 area). The data covers the year of 2014. We inferred the mobility basically by two forms: one given by two consecutive calls, and other given by only one call. The first generated results like O-D matrices, and the latter generated results like visiting detection rank over four shifts of each day.

keywordVocabulary.value: Metropolitan Region of Rio de Janeiro
The cell phone covering area that includes all municipalities of the MRRJ

files.description: This is a larger geographic partitioning of the study area. It is called "traffic zones" by the transportation's secretary of Rio de Janeiro.
files.label: MRRJ_21_area_traffic_zones_partitioning.zip

dataFile.description: This is a larger geographic partitioning of the study area. It is called "traffic zones" by the transportation's secretary of Rio de Janeiro.

files.description: This is the shape file of the union of the set of the cell phone towers, approximating the census bounds.
files.label: MRRJ_21_area_union_set_towers.zip

dataFile.description: This is the shape file of the union of the set of the cell phone towers, approximating the census bounds.

files.description: One O-D matrix per day. The population expansion factor is adaptive, which means that it varies along the year according to the call activity made by the cell phone users.
files.label: MRRJ_ordinary_mobility_given_by_two_calls_adaptive_expansion.tab

dataFile.description: One O-D matrix per day. The population expansion factor is adaptive, which means that it varies along the year according to the call activity made by the cell phone users.

files.description: One O-D matrix per day. The population expansion factor is fixed. This factor is a simple coefficient obtained by the census population over the cell phone users detected as living in the same geographic partitioning. It is fixed because it does not varies along the year.
files.label: MRRJ_ordinary_mobility_given_by_two_calls_fixed_expansion.tab

dataFile.description: One O-D matrix per day. The population expansion factor is fixed. This factor is a simple coefficient obtained by the census population over the cell phone users detected as living in the same geographic partitioning. It is fixed because it does not varies along the year.

files.description: One O-D matrix per day. There is no population expansion factor, only the traveling counting detected directly from the cell phone users. This may be useful for those who want to create their own population expansion factor.
files.label: MRRJ_ordinary_mobility_given_by_two_calls_no_expansion.tab

dataFile.description: One O-D matrix per day. There is no population expansion factor, only the traveling counting detected directly from the cell phone users. This may be useful for those who want to create their own population expansion factor.

files.description: The estimation given by only one cell phone call would not be directly considered as O-D, so we consider it as a visiting probability from the place of the presumed domicile. For each visit over each shift, it is considered only the most visited of all the visiting places of each active cell phone user. If a tie happens, it is considered the far place from home.
files.label: MRRJ_ordinary_visiting_given_by_one_call_over_shifts.tab

dataFile.description: The estimation given by only one cell phone call would not be directly considered as O-D, so we consider it as a visiting probability from the place of the presumed domicile. For each visit over each shift, it is considered only the most visited of all the visiting places of each active cell phone user. If a tie happens, it is considered the far place from home.
